title: Printrbot Simple Metal RPi Camera Bed Mount

description.text:
This mount attaches to the print bed so that objects stay motionless in timelapse videos. The design is snap together, requiring no hardware or tools. You can choose which arm file to print based on what side of the print bed you want to mount the camera (arm_flipped.stl is the one in my photo). I also printed "tiltArm.stl" at 95% to get a snug fit. Here is a video of the resulting timelapse:
http://youtu.be/5IWEMwB5P8c There is a large hole in front of the camera that accommodates this $3 wide angle cell phone lens:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005C3CSXC/ To make this thing I mashed together these three wonderful projects. Raspberry pi camera case/enclosure
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:92208 Raspberry Pi camera case for Printrbot Simple
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:404654 Printrbot Simple Corner Accessory Mount
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-simple-corner-accessory-mount EDIT Jan. 22, 2015: I added arm_reinforced.stl which adds more support to the arm part to reduce camera wobble. If you need it flipped, you can flip the part in your slicer.

I have been playing around with personalizing items by adding relief shaped text with the 'WRITE' plugin, on top of them.
Now I have a better procedure: I print the text in a one layer hight and after a filament change, I print the object that has before been boolean differenced with the same text block.
This is a speedlimit sign with 3 colors :-)

  • Please 'LIKE' before collecting!
    Thomas

This sign will be printed with 2 intermediate filament changes.
==> Be aware: extruder and Bed stay hot during filament exchange !! Manage with care!
Tip: Heat up the bed pretty hot, for nicest finish of the multicolor layer. Glass beds will give good results in PLA. I make them 80 + degrees Centigrade for good bonding.
Start with printing either the one layer circumference (cirle) , or the speed limit (50). It does'n matter, as long as these two come first.
(Tip: remove the Gcode that cools the bed and extruder, or stay close and reset the temps.
After the print stops, remove the skirt and change the filament
Home the extruder and print the other insert with new filament.
After the print stops, remove the skirt and change the filament
Home the extruder and print the last piece (3-white), which will cover all of the prints already on the bed.
Now zero the bed and extruder temps and wait for the bed to cool down.
Beware: White will be a lit transparent, so make your engravements darker, not vice-versa !
Thomas
www.3daybreaker.blogspot.com

title: Clip-on basket for Ikea Kura Bed

description.text:
Edit 2/7/2015: Added STL for complete basket, which prints OK with external support and may be more convenient than printing the bottom separately and gluing. Basket and clip for Ikea Kura bed. Included OpenSCAD files so it is very customizable. Should work on other beds as well with simple adjustment of dimensions.
http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/80253814/

Print upside down to avoid need for support material. Print bottom separately and glue on. Make sure that the bottom cools completely before removing from the printer bed, as it will deform when warm.
Clip-basket interface is a bit tight; might need to adjust. OpenSCAD files included, allowing adjustment of angle, thickness, spacing, etc. Update: also included STL for full basket printed as one piece. Needs support material on outside for this.

description.text:
Walk into most any Ace Hardware or hobby store and you'll find an assortment of hollow tubes in different sizes and metals I've chosen to update my Smartrap to use these craft tubes as smooth rods. I find they have a number of advantages over the conventional solid smooth rods. They are:
  • smoother than conventional rods offered by hardware stores
  • cheaper than rods made specially for linear motion
  • readily available at hardware and craft stores
  • much, much lighter than conventional smooth rods
    • The tubes come in different sizes. Smaller sized tubes can slip easily in and out of larger tubes with barely any play between them. This means that the tubes can also make suitable bearings. Bearings made from these tubes are smoother than printed bearings, but are cheaper and much easier to source than LM6UU bearings. For the Smartrap, I use 7/32" brass tubes for smooth rods and 1/4" aluminum tubes for bearings (shown above). The bearing tubes are a few hundred microns larger in diameter than the conventional 6mm id bearings, so some adaptation is necessary. I've uploaded the adapters I use to convert the LM6UU bearing holders for use with the 1/4"" tube bearings.

9/8/14 - So I've finally updated my smartrap and tested the rods. The y axis works beautifully - very smooth, remains level with the ground even without use of glass supports. The x axis I've had consistent problems getting to be level with the ground, however I increasingly suspect the problem lies with some of the other updates I've made. Somewhere between version 0.45 and the present the Smartrap reduced the number of components to the bottom plate, and now it seems there's nothing in place to keep the z axis rods plumb with the base board.

comments.text: Cool, but it looks like your printer needs some serious calibrating!
comments.author: CertifiedNerd

comments.text: Anything you suggest in particular? Maybe something to do with nozzle diameter? Right now I'm printing with a 0.8mm nozzle diameter. Gives faster turnaround and stronger prints, but I do believe the quality suffers.
comments.author: CertifiedNerd

comments.text: If your motors are all calibrated properly and your axis's are level than no, not really with out seeing it in person. I did have a scratch built 1/16" nozzle (no joke) for a little while because I had to make some big parts really quickly. It took a lot of tinkering with extrusion widths and temperatures and such to get it to work, with reasonable quality prints.

I did just remember that I had to tighten the belts on my printer because they had loosened over the 2 years I've had it. It took me a while to realize it was the belts, all I could see was terribly aligned layers.
comments.author: CertifiedNerd

comments.text: This is such an interesting yet insanely simple idea.  When I built my first CNC machine, I used bushings I liberated from dead inkjet printers and for the most part, commercial laser and inkjet printers also using this sort of concept.  Thank you for this.  As an additional note, I would be curious to see how well these tubes hold up as you extend the dimensions of the SmartRap.  For example, in my larger 3-in-1 version, I noted that at 18" of travel in X, the leverage imposed by the cantilevered arm was substantial, especially whenever the hot end encountered an obstacle (e.g. if it hit the bed or a bit of plastic being squished onto the bed).
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Will post back on results. I'm still in the process of updating my Smartrap from version 0.45 and there's a lot of parts that will need to be swapped out. Just by toying with it though it feels like the motion is very smooth.

Gracias Coribel. Lo cierto es que fue de las primeras cosas que hice con la impresora y aun no controlaba mucho el tema de las temperaturas, velocidades y demás. Vi que Bq recomendaba 215º, pero en otros documentos e información del PLA hablaban de rangos de entre 190ºC y 210ºC. Despueés de aquello he hecho muchas pruebas, y noto poca diferencia, Suelo imprimir a unos 204ºC, y cuando tengo puentes o voladizos suelo bajarla un poco, por aquello de que enfrie y endurezca más rápido. Cuando he usado el PLA flex, si noto diferencia con la temperatura. si la pongo a menos de 210ºC, no se pegan igual de bien las capas, y se me ha llegado a romper alguna pieza.
Un saludo y gracias!

description.text: The glass plate on my leapfrog creatr is able to slightly move in the y-direction of the printer. I suspected that this caused some y-direction deviations in some of my prints. In an effort to stabilize the glass plate so that it cannot move in the y-direction (or x-direction), I designed these clips. There are front and side versions, and thin/thick ones. I used two thin and one thick clip on the front of my creatr. Now the glass plate is rigidly in place.

Settings used on Simplify3d, with the Leapfrog Creatr Dual extruder printer. Material: ABS
Extrusion width: auto
Retraction distance: 2.5 mm
Primary layer height: 0.2 mm
Skirt offset: 0 mm
Skirt outlines: 3
Interior fill percentage: 15 %
Infill angles: 45, -45
Bed temp: 80 C
Extruder temp: 220 C
Default print speed: 1500 mm/min
X/Y axis movement speed: 1600 mm/min
Z-axis movement speed: 600 mm/min Screws need to be screwed out as far as they can be, however you do not need to remove the glass plate completely. Leave the two rear screws in. Lift the front of the glass plate slightly to place the clip on it.

title: Logicflight Y6m - Simplest & Durable mini Drone

description.text:
Logicflight is based in the beatiful city of Berlin, we build customized UAVs & do aerial research for over 2 years.
We wanted to publish our first prototype called Logicflight Y6m. It's a tricopter with motor redundancy. We kept the design as simple as possible because in the past we have built complex models from third parties and we know how painful can be to build or repair models.
For an intermediate user it might take between 2 to 4 hours to assemble this model.
Feel free to ask any questions on the comments, we are happy to help and also to receive feedback to improve this model.
Disclaimer: this is a work in progress and an experimental model, we take no responsibility for misuse or any kind of accidents that might occur. Always protect yourself when activating motors, and threat the electronics and batteries with care, as they might burn or explode. In case of questions or doubts please contact us at [email protected]

Materials:
  • 6x Turnigy 1811 brushless Outrunner 2900kv
  • 6x 6A Turnigy ESCs
  • 6x 5x3x3 Propellers (3xCW & 3xCCW)
  • 1x 35C 2S 2000mah to 3000mah Lithium battery
  • 1x Flight Management Unit
  • 1x 4CH to 8CH Receiver, depending on your needs.
    1) We recommend to print Arms & Holders with raft and support material (we used PVA + PLA).
    2) Body can be printed without support.
    3) Once that pieces are printed, insert the motors inside the motor holders.
    4) Use 3x M2 short screws and nuts to join the motor holders together.
    5) Use 3x M3 screws and nuts to join the holders with the arms.
    6) Use 3x M3 screws and nuts to join the arms with the main body.
    7) Mount the ESCs using velcro and take care of using cable binders to protect cables from hitting the propellers.
    8) Mount your electronics (FMU, Receiver, GPS, Sensors, etc.)
    9) Fly and enjoy!
    In case of any question please add a comment, we are happy to help you.

Create your own bob-omb themed tissue dispenser! The ready-to-print models of the eyes and feet are made to fit this off-the-shelf tissue box perfectly. For added fun, check out the instructions for how to bob-omb-ify other objects around the house / shop.

The impetus for this project came when I realized that my tissue dispenser looked a lot like a bobomb from Mario. All it needed were eyes and feet. This project comes in two flavors: ready-to-print and customizable.

For those that want to jump right into the printing, you'll first want to pick up a tissue dispenser available here. The following files are ready to print and are designed specifically to fit this tissue dispenser model. bobomb_eyes.stl bobomb_foot_left.stl bobomb_foot_right.stl

I used a Makerbot Replicator to print all the parts, configured with the default 'Standard' print settings. 0.2mm 10% infill 230°C extruder | 110°C build plate 90mm/s extruder | 150mm/s travel rake + supports
I printed the eyes oriented with their backs to the build plate. This way, the unevenness from the supports is hidden.

I ran into trouble when trying to print both feet at the same time; the rake would often lift up and the parts would collide on the build platform. Printing them individually, however, everything went smoothly (hence the separate files).

After printing, use a pair of pliers to tear away the support material and an exacto-knife to smooth out the edges. I found the eyes were a little translucent, letting the adhesive show through; so, I opted to coat the backs of the eyes in white house paint. Use either glue or tacky gum (the kind you hang posters with) to attach the eyes to the tissue box. I left the feet freely attached since the ridge on the bottom of the box kept them fixed but allowed them to freely rotate.
Don't feel like buying a tissue box? Got a different object you'd like to bobomb-ify? No problem! With a little more work, you can craft eyes and feet to fit other objects perfectly.
For this project, I used Blender to model the tissue box and fit the eyes and feet to its profile. The original source file (bobomb_parameterized.blend) is attached.

In the attached file, everything is modeled in millimeters. The eyes and feet are parametrized such that you can substitute a different model for the body and they will fit to the new object. After adding a model of the new object you want to use as the body, you'll need to change the "target" of the following modifiers:
Boolean Mirror

Mirror Shrinkwrap You can then reposition and resize the eyes and feet to match the scale and proportions of the new body object. *Pro Tip* : Disable the boolean modifier temporarily while adjusting the size and position of the feet. It's an expensive operation and will bog down most machines. For reference, I've also attached an example file (bobomb_mug.blend) that uses a standard coffee mug as the base object.

title: Delta Robot v1 with three arms

description.text:
All my designs & progress available @ Marginally Clever.
You can buy the updated version of this kit
Video
Mention in Forbes
Scale model of a 3 armed delta robot used in automated manufacturing. I'm looking for better ball joints. A universal joint that mates to M3 would be fantastic.
If you use one of my designs, please let me know! I'd love to see what you make with it and share with others who are interested.

Kit with all parts available at http://marginallyclever.com.
Acquire three sets of http://www.pololu.com/catalog/product/733
Acquire three hobby servos.
Acquire an Arduino UNO or better.
Acquire a 9v1a power supply.
Acquire a small breadboard.
print one end effector, three bicep, and three mounting brackets.
Assemble as in the photographs. Hot glue the servo horns onto the biceps.
Upload the code from the github project @ https://github.com/i-make-robots/Delta-Robot
Share your experience in our forums @ http://marginallyclever.com/forum/

comments.text:
Hi Makers!
I used this model in project Oktopod Studio http://www.oktopodstudio.com
Dear Dan Royer, thanks for the model. Our first run you can see on https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LosqAfxbljM
comments.author: milanromic

comments.text: Featured in Forbes! http://www.forbes.com/sites/andygreenberg/2013/07/22/pin-punching-robot-can-crack-your-phones-security-code-in-less-than-24-hours/http://www.forbes.com/sites/an...
comments.author: i-make-robots

comments.text:
This kit has had a major overhaul. The next edition is available
through my store right now and will be released on thingiverse on or
about october 18.
comments.author: i-make-robots

comments.text: Are you going to upload the v2 design? October 18th has passed... I'm probably going to build this version anyway if v2 isn't posted, but I have access to a lasercutter.
comments.author: i-make-robots

comments.text: There seems to be a lot of demand for delta robots, so I've been overhauling the design for a v3. I should have news before march. about the date... http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/community-premiere-date-addressed-380346http://www.hollywoodreporter.c... is all I can say.
comments.author: Andrew1618033

comments.text:
The round hole looks perfect to use the RepMan toolhead mounting.
That would e.g. make it compatible with the existing Dremel milling head and the BfB extruders. (Can't hurt )
comments.author: MarcusWolschon

comments.text: Great work. Your design with the three baseplate giving the perfect angle inspired me to resume my delta robot project. I haven't build it completely yet, but have printed the base (needed to file them a little bit for them to fit together, but not much), mounted the servos and made an improvement of the biceps (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44656)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: ahd71

comments.text: If you're looking for something to do, redesign the bicep I made so that the inset for the servo horn is on the "top".  In the current model the inset creates a large overhang that some printers (including mine) have trouble with.  I will bow to your model-fu if you can do it with less plastic.
comments.author: ahd71

comments.text: First off, shame on you for beating me to this design. I have the exact ball joints and threaded rods sitting here on my desk waiting for me to finish printing a design I'd been working on. I guess I'll have to throw in with you now.
comments.author: buffington

comments.text: Shame? On ME? The only shame is that I made one out of aluminum (http://letsmakerobots.com/node/27651)http://letsmakerobots.com/node... before I had a 3D printer.
comments.author: buffington

comments.text: • I guess the question was how the servos was fixed to the base plate - and I have the answer :-) Friction, I printed (in PLA) and mounted servos and it is very tight like they were glued but they aren't. The "innerwalls" was/is a great design to give a little bit of flex.
comments.author: i-make-robots

comments.text: The inner walls was intended to save ABS.  No point filling 40% of wasted space with valuable plastic, right?
comments.author: ahd71

description.text:
This is a "Jelly Roll" protein. Not a protein found in Jelly Rolls, but a kind of protein fold:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beta_barrel#Jelly_roll
This one is based on PDB structure 2QZ3, a "family 11 glycoside hydrolase", aka, xylanase:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore.do?structureId=2qz3
STL file created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/
The protein backbone is represented in "cartoon" form.
Successfully printed by a Replicator 2 in PLA using MakerWare(TM) 2.4.1.24, standard resolution (3 shells, 25% infill), with raft and supports.

title: silent 3 bladed prop -  I got the equation curves down in inventor.

description.text:
Uppdate 29.11.15
Added 9X4.5 blade sett, (Prop4) i hadent done this for a while so i hope i got it right. I finally got the equation curves in inventor all set, if somone wants a spesific airfoil profile let me know.
This has less tip turbulence and makes a lot less noice
I use it as a silent replacement for 5-7" props for my quad.
3 mm axel
print as solid.
I print it on hight resolution and treat it with acetone vapour
I have upploaded an inventor file with a naca profile equation curve, feel free to make any wing profile by simply tweeking the numbers.

Equation curve in inventor.
thickchordt5(0.2969sqrt((1 in)/chord)-(0.1260t1 in)/chord-(0.3516t^31 in^2)/(chord^2 )+(0.2843t^51 in^3)/(chord^3 )-(0.1015t^7*1 in^4)/(chord^4 ))
where:
• c is the chord length,
• x is the position along the chord from 0 to c,
• y is the half thickness at a given value of x (centerline to surface), and
• t is the maximum thickness as a fraction of the chord (so 100 t gives the last two digits in the NACA 4-digit denomination).
You need to add chord and thick as variables in inventor (the fx button) before compiling the equation curve,
PS ! The part file mustbe in inches!!!!!!
The foil must be made in 2 sections one for the top curve and one for the lower just add "-" in front of the lover airfoil curve.

Wall-mounted flyer holder for A6 flyers.

This is a box with holes for SAV-MKI electronic and P3Steel chassis

This is a box with holes for SAV-MKI electronic and P3Steel chassis. Be careful with the holes in P3Steel because right and left big brackets haven't got symmetric holes. So you must verify that box holes match brackets holes.

This stool is for TenkaizuBudokai 3rd (Stool contest at Ogaki Mini Maker 2014).
  • 3D print.
  • Cut MDF using a laser cutting machine.
  • Assemble all parts.
    Material : PLA, MDF2.5mm 300×300mm 5sheets.
    Size : W270,H340,D230
    [tools]
    3D printer : Makerbot Replicator 5th
    Laser cutting machine : Trotec speedy 300
    [Software]
    Rhinoceros, Grasshopper, Python, Illustrator
    [Link]
    Stool contest: http://www.facebook.com/TenkaizuBudokai
    f.Labo: http://f-labo.tumblr.com/
This should make fitting a KX171 camera to your TBS Discovery easier !

I haven't included any holes since my ToM won't handle that much accuracy, just drill 1mm holes after printing.
Also, center square is slightly bigger to allow minimal tilt.

In today's world of NSA and RAT software it's better to have a choice when somebody can see you through your own webcam.  
I'm attaching OpenScad files to create your own project which fits your webcam.  
FU NSA!

If you have MSI GT683 laptop - just print StopSpying_GT683_convex.stl and slide in gently between those two rubber blocks (no glue needed).  
For different type of notebook you can either print StopSpying.stl and use some double-sided tape to stick it in or just modify my project using OpenScad to fit your needs.

title: Simple top mounted filament reel holder for Kossel mini

description.text:
Top mounted filament reel stands for a mini kossel delta type printer.
Requires a 6mm rod (I used some carbon fibre rod that same stuff as is used for the diagonal rods on a lot of mini kossel designs, you could use anything that'll fit).
Should fit just about any 1kg reel. I have quite a variety now, of varying widths and internal and external diameters, and they all fit fine.

• 2 of these stands
  • ~250mm of 6mm diameter carbon fibre rod or other <=6mm rod e.g. threaded steel rod
  • 4 x M3 nuts
  • 4 x 8mm x M3 bolts

(most settings will probably work, this is not a high precision part)
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 25% infill
  • 1mm perimeters

    Troubleshooting

    If you find the rod is being slowly pulled through the stands as the reel revolves, just stick a little blue tape on the ends of the rod (or just on one end since it usually will only travel in one direction).

title: LumiDome magnifier holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
LumiDomes are terrific ball-shaped 3X magnifiers that are useful and fun -- they're great for the kids, too!
What I particularly like about them is that you can view a much larger area without moving the lens than you could with a regular magnifying glass -- you do have to move your head around, but the magnifier can be held in the same spot and does not need to be rotated.
You can get the 3-inch version from RadioShack for about $6.
I made a stand to hold my dome so that I can use it for quick soldering jobs on tiny components.

I printed this on my acceleration-enabled ThingOMatic in PLA at 70 mm/sec, 0.3 mm layer height, with 3 extra shells. You will need to gently press fit the dome into the holder, but it's a loose enough hold that you can remove the dome when you're finished. LumiDomes are available from RadioShack: http://www.radioshack.com/product/index.jsp?productId=3353492

title: Modular Heart Box for Valentines day

description.text: Modular heart shaped box with a swivel hinge. Stack as many layers as you like in as many colours as you like!

Print a lid and as many boxes as you like. There is also an optional base (if you want to cover the bottom hinge hole). Print out connectors and clip it all together. Works very nicely and makes a good Valentine gift box.  
The swivel hinge mechanism uses Pin Connectors V3 by Emmett and they work really well. You can use this design to make stackable boxes of any shape e.g. animals. I found that for an 8mm radius hole, a 7mm radius pin works well.  
I printed this half size with a 1.2mm wall and 50% infill  because I am a bit low on red and pink plastic. Prints out OK at 1/2 size, but the walls are a bit thin. Printing at 0.75 size with 100% infill or full size with 50% infill would have been better.  
I printed in PLA in a nice red I got from Ultimaker and Cherry Blossom Pink from Faberdashery.

author: wanderermg

title: FlexMesh 2.1 Snap Together Flexible Chainmail Mesh
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
FlexMesh 1.0 is fun. Now let's take it to the next level. Though the basic geometry remains the same, pins have been swapped out in favor of nubs. Objects connected via nubs are much easier to construct and experiment with. Now our FlexMesh creations are more durable and allow for almost limitless configurability of colors and geometries. FlexMesh 2 demonstrates how to work through even more of the challenges of today's low-cost 3D printing technology...

  • We can use multiple spot colors in our 3D creations.

  • We can quickly and easily explore topologies and geometries.

  • We can snap together a shape then take it apart and reuse parts over and over again.

  • We can expand the repertoire of FlexMesh-compatible shapes to explore, build and play with.
    • FlexMesh 2.1 is here. The downloads section now includes 5 & 6 sided shapes and a more rounded family of 5 new shapes. Read the release notes for full details. TriSphere is another flexible mesh pattern worth exploring. Check out the "I Made One" and "Remixes" sections for a sampling of FlexMesh objects you can make. An Inventor Studios Tinkercad tutorial walks students through this design. Follow the entire collection to refine your modeling skills.

Read the FlexMesh 2.1 release notes for design changes and printing details. FlexMesh 2 prints well in ABS and PLA with 2 shells and 10% to 20% infill. Just about any reasonably tuned FDM or SLA printer can be used. Slic3r, Makerware and Simplify3D are all able to accurately slice the shapes. FlexMesh 2.1 is the 23th lap through our internal innovation cycle. It's not perfect, though many earlier shortcomings have been resolved. The most significant challenge has been the spacing of the nubs, or bumps, on the connector shapes and the indents, or holes, in the Mains. (Duo's, Tri's, Quad's,Penta's & Hexa's) Some printer/material combinations result in snug fits while others produce very loose ones. Read the release notes for furthere details. Note: Here's how to distinguish which printed connector variation you're holding... The SubWide shape has a subtle 'W' on top. Each of the Sub's released in the 2.1 release has a number embossed on one side between nubs. If you don't see either of these markings then you probably have an original Sub. FlexMesh shapes snap together using a twisting motion. Watch the video in the gallery of this thing to see how this twisting motion works. For best results, twist the nub into the hole from the front of the main. Additional STL files have been added for printing large quantities of parts. Have fun and please take the time to submit remixes for the benefit of all.

comments.text: Cyclone posed a question over in the Monopoly board remix about how to determine which colored pieces to use when creating a FlexMesh pattern of an image. He suggested software, but I think you could accomplish almost the same thing using a stencil of a mesh. The outline of each FlexMesh piece would be printed on a sheet of vellum or overlaid in a drawing program on top of an image of the pattern you're trying to create. This would allow you to see the dominate color inside each FlexMesh piece as you snap together a mesh depicting that image. This approach wouldn't automatically count the number of pieces of each color needed, but you could do that yourself.

So, if I adjusted my bed height differently for just the subs, I would be good. But, like you said, adding a small fillet would be nice, and give the pieces a more polished smooth-edge feeling. And then I could be lazy and just keep the same bed height for these prints.

remixed_from.author: jedynak
remixed_from.title: Really High accuracy adjustable Z Endstop for Prusa

description.text: i just fixed something please redownload it, if you havent printed it yet. I made my own endstop based on jedynaks design. it uses two bic pens for smooth rods eliminating any slop, also the m4 screw is supported on both ends so it wiggles less. this is still a work in progress so any suggestions are welcome.

materials:
2 20mm m3 screws
4 m3 washers
2 m3 nuts
1 long m4 screw
1 long spring that will fit over m4 screw, approximately 20 to 30mm long
1 m4 nut
2 bic pens. make sure you use support material for the part that over hangs, it should be pretty easy to remove. drill the holes for the bic pens in the main frame so they fit in snugly.
drill the endstop holder holes so it slides over the bic pens but with minimal slop.
install the m4 nut in the nut trap
put m4 screw through top hole in frame, then slide spring on, then place the endstop holder in. i recommend sanding the angled faces so they are smooth. in reality those can probably be done away with but for now it will stay.

remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

description.text:
I built Lyman's spooler to go along with my Filastruder.  I made a couple of small tweaks. -   
Using nuts inside the latex rollers made for bumpy movement between them, so I simply printed cylinders to put inside the tubes instead.  
I mounted the voltage regulators on the front, since I can't walk around to the back to make adjustments.  Still to come- knobs for the adjustment screw so I don't have to keep fiddling with a tiny screwdriver.  I would also like to dress them up with a cover.  
Update-  
I changed the puller to a Wade's Reloaded extruder with a stepper, but it didn't improve filament tolerance when pulling plastic directly from the die.  Variations in pressure in the extruder normally change the speed of output while maintaining the diameter.  When stretching the plastic directly from the die, the speed can't change so the diameter did instead.  For the sake of simplicity, I switched the motor back to a gear motor and am letting the filament drop into a loop on the way to the puller.  I'm still working on a method of syncing the uptake of the puller with the output of the extruder.  
Instead of a hobbed bolt in the Wade's, I used a 8mm bolt with a 10mm long section of tubing - McMaster.com #5102K442.  
I found that the springs on the motor arms aren't necessary.  I need to make a mount for an adjustment bolt for the spool motor arm to rest on.  Raising the bolt would lift the arm enough to provide a light enough touch on the spool that it would slip when encountering a little tension.  The weight of the motor by itself provides too much traction.  Also I need to do the same thing under the arm of the roller motor to dial in the right distance between the gears.

Follow the directions for the original spooler.  I used more lock nuts to keep the rollers in place.  Spin the threaded rods with a drill to make it easier to place the lock nuts.  Figuring out what order to put them all on and in what direction is a bit tricky.
The z tabs are for mounting bolts to support the motor arms and raise or lower them precisely.
I also updated the gears to increase the ratio in an attempt to improve accuracy.

comments.text: Im currently starting to build the Lyman filament extruder. This is next on my list once thats done. Unrelated question but do you know that size I should drill out the brass nozzle to for 3mm filament?
comments.author: Revolve3D

comments.text: Perhaps to implement skovgaar's suggestion you could put an idler pulley on a spring-loaded arm, then attach the end of the arm to the shaft of a potentiometer and use the potentiometer to control the pulse width.  Running too fast -> too much tension -> pulls pulley and arm -> turns pot -> reduces duty-cycle.  Running too slow -> not enough tension -> spring pulls arm -> turns pot -> increases duty-cycle.
comments.author: charliearmorycom

comments.text: I had the same idea, from one I saw in the video he posted.  I've since changed the rollers to a stepper controlled extruder driven by an Arduino Uno.  The Uno could use PWM to control the spool motor and read the potentiometer.  On the other hand, simply keeping a light enough touch between the spool and the roller that a little tension causes the roller to slip is a much simpler solution.
comments.author: charliearmorycom

comments.text: In model railroading they have the same problem of not being able to run the DC motor below a certain voltage (for super-slow operation) and still have enough torque.  What the high end power supplies do is use Pulse Width Modulation (PWM).  Rather than changing the voltage they change the duty-cycle of the pulses.  Perhaps this would help.
comments.author: charliearmorycom

comments.text: I wish I had seen this project before you got so far along on it, because I think there is a much better way to go about it. I used to work at a movie theater as a projectionist back in the days of actual film, and the projectors I used employed a very good solution to the exact challenge you're facing here. With a film projector (the newer ones, not like in Fight Club and Inglorious Basterds, this kind http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hplGiw7-UpQ)http://www.youtube.com/watch?v... the film must be unspooled/spooled from a 3' reel. The projector would feed the film at a constant rate, but the rate that the big horizontal platters would need to spin varied depending on how much film had been spooled/unspooled since the radius of the reel was constantly changing. There were various tension sensors that were used to control the motor speed depending on how much slack was there. What you're doing has obviously worked, but modulating motor speeds/torques based on direct measurement of tension seems like it would be way less finicky than relying on slippage (which can be quite inconsistent)
comments.author: skovgaar

comments.text: Does the tension sensor look like this - http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_detailpage&v=hplGiw7-UpQ#t=112shttp://www.youtube.com/watch?f... The slipping is simple to execute. Maybe there would be a way to make a lever that will actually turn the knob on the voltage regulator as the filament pushes it up and down. The tension on the reel isn't that critical though, it's the tension of the rollers pulling the filament from the extruder that must be absolutely consistent. That said, the tension from the reel can't be so much that it starts to drag the filament through the rollers.
comments.author: skovgaar

3D Printed TriPod addon, for Taking Panoramic Images with your normal point-and-shoot camera. Adjustable for the Nodal Point of your Camera.
This is build for my Small Canon C610 Snap-and-shoot Camera, and should work with most Smaller Cameras

DON NOT TRY TO PRINT COMPLETE.STL. It just for Display purposes.
  • Print one of each STL file
  • Mount the Tripod Holder to your Tripod using a 4-5mm Bolt/Nut
  • Glue the zaxis and x Axis Slider to the Connector_x_z Block
  • Slide the xAxis in the Tropod Holder.
  • Connect the yaxisholder and zaxisholder with a 3mm Nut/Bolt
  • Put this over the ZAxis Slider
  • Put the Y Axis Slider into the YAxis Holder
  • Connect your Camera to the yAxis Slider
    Now you can Adjust your x/y/z Axis to get the Camera Nodal point for picture perfect Panoramic Images

UPDATE UPDATE UPDATE: Improved parts, fixed errors, made all parts parametric. Source is at https://github.com/prusajr/PrusaMendel .
Make sure that your printer has 200x200 active area. Detailed build instructions are at http://www.reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Mendel

title: flamewheel clone whirlwind FY450 16mm tube arm holder mount

description.text:
In case you want to replace the plastic arms on your copter frame with 16mm carbon fiber or aluminum tubes.
Fits my "whirlwind FY450" clone frame from HK, probably also others but I am not sure about the hole pattern of those.
Because the holes of the upper and lower frame piece are not exactly in line, the two holes are tilted so that you can still use 3mm bolt through - holds the arm just fine only with the two bolts, I also use ziptie throuht the two central holes (see image). Added version 2 - in case you have frame which uses 40mm brass standofs for battery tray, or you just want to have more space between the upper and lower frame pieces.

I printed in ABS, two loops and 50% infill. I guess you could use less infill, the real stress would be held by the bolts.
I had to drill the holes to size with 3mm drill. I printed v2 with 25% infill which worked just fine, probably could go even lower.

author: Dapr

title: Parametric z leadscrew nut clamp for Huxley

description.text: This is a parametric part for Huxley and for Mendel variants (its function is served by part of another assembly in a standard Mendel. For Huxley, it replaces two parts of x-axis-clamp 4off.stl, should print in less space than one of the original parts, and (like my y-bar clamps) requires no screws! It has the added advantage of functioning as an anti-backlash nut, and was inspired by the anti-backlash nuts in the Prusa Mendel, but it uses the springiness of the printed part instead of a (vitamin) coil spring. This part is untested, as I'm working on my printer at the moment.

Insert the x rods through the holes on the sides, and a nut into each of the hexagonal recesses. Begin screwing the leadscrew into one of the nuts, and squeeze the nuts together before you start threading the leadscrew into the second nut. The tension on the nuts will keep them seated in the recesses, clamp the x-axis rods, and prevent backlash all at once!

This application can visualize Gcodes and simulate a real 3D print.
GCode Simulator recognizes the print speeds and can simulate the print in realtime, but you can also speedup the prints (fast forward,slow motion). Each layer is painted in a different color to see how a layer overlaps with the layer below. GCodeSimulator Home page: http://3dprintapps.de/ Video of GCodeSimulator in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i1SY2N21EDQ GCodeSimulator let you to check how your print should turn out, making it easier to spot errors and fix them instead of wasting filament. If the print object looks ok you can directly send it over Wifi to GCodePrintr (Android) to print it.
GCodePrintr - 3D Printing for ANDROID available
Allows real 3D printing from an Android device
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=de.dietzm.gcodesimulator In addition GCodeSimulator analyses the Gcode file and prints additional information like:
It calculates various print details like
-print time
-used filament
-yx move distance
-print object dimension
-average print speeds
-number of layers
-layer details
-speed distribution / Acceleration
-weight and price of the printed object
-much more ... It also allows to debug your gcode by stepping through it line by line and show the results. (debug mode) Developed for my reprap printer but works with other printers (e.g. makerbot, ultimaker,...) as well, tested with Silc3r and skeinforge gcodes. Download the latest Version V130

Add GCode Simulator as post-processing script in Slic3r !! GCode Simulator for ANDROID available
Allows real 3D printing from an Android device (not just simulation)

Handle gcode files with Z-Lifts and negative coordinates (auto center on bed).
Show details of the printed model (e.g. overall print time, size, layers,..) How to start GCodeSimulator on Windows/Linux/MacOS
GCodeSimulator is written in Java and therefore requires a Java Runtime Environment (>=1.6) to be installed on the System. You can get the Java JRE from www.java.com (Oracle).
Once Java is installed you can start GCodeSimulator by double click on the GCodeSimulator.jar file. (Open with java from explorer or your favorite file browser.) If this does not work, please start GCodeSimulator by calling java from the command line
java -jar GCodeSimulator.jar [gcode_file] [gcode_file] is optional , if not specified then a browse dialog will open. IMPORTANT: Due to a bug in the linux java jre do not choose a file from the "recent file" list, this will cause a crash. Instead go to the full path of the file and open it there. The GCode Print simulator can be controlled with the following hotkeys:
i/o=Zoom
+/-=Speed
n=NextLayer
r=Restart
p=Pause
q=Quit I have tested it with many Slic3r gcodes and some skeinforge gcodes. But GCodes can be very complex, therefore I'm pretty sure there will still be bugs.
Z-Lifts might causes problems and negative coordinates as well (fixed with V0.65). Relative positioning is not supported yet.
Feedback is highly welcome !

My printer is a Rapman from Bitsfrombytes and on these machines the coordinate (X0,Y0) is the middle of the printbed.
It seems that for GcodeSimulator this coordinate is at the bottom-left corner of the screen.
Therefore the simulation occurs in that corner and can't be completely seen.
It could be a good point to be able to tell the program where the origin is with some X and Y offset. Just an idea...
I also know that some Gcode for BfB machines might be different than for other machines.
So maybe it won't be able to completely simulate BfB gcode.

comments.text: Hi ,what is the optimal configuration for android's tablet ? Processor , RAM, memory ... It s great apps for running your 3d printer
comments.author: mana

comments.text:
Most important is that the usb-host feature is supported by the tablet. Memory of 512-1024MB is fine. Larger gcode files will require more memory. E.g. a 300000 line gcode requires ~50MB memory. Single core CPU is ok but dual/quad core CPU has some buffer for additional calculations.
I have 2 tablets which run fine: Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and Trekstor Surftab Breeze 7.0

A very small extruder, ideal for multi-color or multi-material 3D-printers.
The design is derivated from the multi-material-extruder from RepRapPro.

The original design of this extruder comes from Adrian Bowyer (first seen on vimeo http://vimeo.com/54462325), I have just slightly modified it. The extruder body is modified to use a tongue to hold the bowden tube - so eMaker-Huxley and RepRapPro hot-ends should fit without problems (and without any adaptions). The second change to the original design is the screw hole for the idler (idler screw only can be removed, if the stepper motor is dismounted). And I have made a change to the grub hole in the small gear to make the nut retainer a little stronger. If you want to have a look to the original files please visit: github.com/reprappro/Mendel. Update V2 (3 Feb 2013): assembly instruction added; V2-extruder-block added (moved filament-drive-axis 0.5mm for better fit of hobbed bolt; larger hole for idler screw); deeper hole for motor flange (better motor fitting if your printed bridges are not perfect).
Update (24 March 2013): OpenSCAD sources added (they are not really nice - but better than nothing) Watch this extruder in action: YouTube ( http://www.youtube.com/user/3DAndyAustria ) - there you can find an assembly instruction video also. Some pictures of the mounted extruder could be found on Flickr ( http://www.flickr.com/3d_andy ) - there you can see also the mounting kits for M8 or M6 threaded rods (and of course assembly pictures). Needed parts to build one extruder-drive:
  • 1 of each: extruder-body.stl, small-gear.stl, large-gear.stl, tongue.stl
  • 1 M3x5 set screw
  • 1 M3x12 bolts
  • 2 M3x16 bolts
  • 2 M3x30 bolts
  • 4 M3 washers
  • 4 M3 nuts
  • 1 M3 nylock nut
  • 3 623ZZ bearings
  • 1 hobbed bolt (need one? Feel free to write a private message on thingiverse or an e-mail to 3d.andy(AT)gmx.net)
    • For mounting the extruder to the top of a Mendel/Prusa (with M8 rods) you will need:
  • 2 mendel-mount-front.stl
  • 1 mendel-mount-rear.stl
  • 3 M3 nuts
  • 1 M3x16 bolt
  • 2 M3x25 bolts
    • For mounting the extruder to M6 rods you will need:
  • 2 huxley-mount.stl
  • 2 M3 nuts
  • 2 M3x20 bolts
    • Good luck!

title: P3Steel X carriage adapter for extruder

description.text:
Adapter between X axis carriage and the extruder.
Designed for use with the suggested parts for P3steel.
  • Carriage for extruders 30mm, 50mm and 80mm: https://github.com/jbabio/P3Steel/blob/master/Proteins/X_Carriage/Carriage_1/x-carriage.stl
  • Extruder 50mm: https://github.com/algspd/asimov/blob/master/piezas/impresoras/prusa3_steel/gregs-wade-v3-motor.stl
    • Very solid provisional part, fixed with M3x25 screws for carriage and M4x40 for the extruder. Shifts the center of extruder less than 5mm.

• Print.
  • Place M4 nuts in the slots.
  • Screw the adapter into the carriage using four M3x25 screws. (recomended: do not use washers, only a nut per screw).
  • Place the extruder on the adapter with the help of two M4x40 screws. Do not tighten the screws yet.
  • Level the extruder, make sure it is at the correct height and tighten the screws.
